Picketty writes, “ultimately for the planet as a whole – there is ample reason to believe that the growth rate will not exceed 1-1.5 percent in the long run, no matter what economic policies are adopted.” Other economists have made similar predictions. And they may be right about the limitations of policy to affect growth. Policies, especially in democracies, are both constrained by, and the product of, the cultures they are intended to serve. In principle, I see no reason why policy should be unable to have a positive influence on long-term economic growth and standards of living, but a prerequisite condition for such policies is the existence of a culture that possesses all the necessary characteristics required to formulate and embrace them.

A culture capable of higher economic and standard of living growth rates would be different to varying degrees from the ones that prevail here and around the world today. Firstly, it would would be relentlessly rational. The scientific method would be embraced not just as a laboratory technique but as the cornerstone of a worldview in which evidence and data rather than vague impressions and emotions served as the basis for both private and collective decision making. Secondly, it would place a much higher value on socially optimal outcomes, and all that such outcomes entail, than we do today.

If this sort of transformation were to take place, humanity would find itself wealthier, happier and collectively far more capable.

Although London & NYC adamantly claim otherwise, derivative contracts can be classified, prospectively, as either very likely to be dysfunctional from the perspective of the economy as a whole, or otherwise. So a paper based on combining recent empirical research by an IMF visiting professor with recognition that not all types of such contracts actually serve the economy of which they are a part explains how such a classification can rationally be made. Available at http://www.authentixcoaches.com/ACdsFCF-1.html, it suggests a charge be levied at the writing or exchange of very-likely-to-be-dysfunctional derivative contracts in order to inhibit the trading of more grossly destabilizing ones. Unlike the FTT touted by financial industry detractors, such a charge would NOT harass the economy's functional financial babies to clear the bath water of dysfunctional ones, but it would be effective in lessening financial instability and also in increasing coherence between an economy's financial and real sectors. Written by a former coach to a manager of trading at a major international the paper also sketches how such a charge might be calibrated over the economic cycle

The U.S. suffered bank panic/depressions in 1819, 1837, 1857, 1873, 1884, 1893, and, 1907 prior to the Great Deprssion. Laissez Faire was the approach to finance in the 19th and first third of the 20th centuries. That came to an end in 1933 with the New Deal which substituted "strict supervision" for hands off.

Ironically, the first thing the New Dealers did was to keep in place the McFadden Act of 1927 signed into law by Calvin Coolidge with Andrew W. Mellon and Herbert Hoover as Secretaries of Treasury and Commerce. The McFadden Act restricted interstate branch banking. One purpose was to protect small banks necessary to the "real economy". Another was the prevention of the concentration of economic and political power such as wielded by J.P. Morgan.

The Glass-Steagall Act implemented deposit insurance to stop the kind of runs on healthy banks seen in "It's a Wonderful Life". The great concern was the "moral hazard" created for bankers with the government guarantee of deposits. To meet this real problem, "strict supervision", in addition to the limits of size, also included separation of investment and commercial banks. Less known, Glass-Steagall placed restrictions on the kind of speculative activities banks could engage in.

It worked. The 78 years and 11 months of financial stability was the longest in American history.

Geithner opposed returning to "strict supervision" of finance?
